reviewText: I want to make it clear that this is a review of the film and not the DVD itself.  I do not own this DVD version.  Sadly, it appears that this film is not available at the time; but hopefully that will be rectified soon.  They certainly do not play it on TCM enough, but if you happen to see it on their schedule I urge you to DVR it and hold on to it as long as possible!Adapted to the big screen from Michael V. Gazzo's stage play, `A Hatful of Rain' is one of those film adaptations that feels a tad too stagey for its own good.  Some plays just cannot translate well, and this is one that still feels like a play, not a film.  That being said, the performances within truly justify its existence, and the stagey feeling is really the only complaint I can muster considering that the script is beautifully fleshed, the actors are in sync and the power of the message is undeniable.The film tells the story of Johnny Pope, a Korean War vet who has a nasty morphine addiction that is oppressing his family.  His brother Polo works to support his brother's habit, and tries his hardest to conceal it from the rest of the family; but even if they are unaware of the particular problem, his problem still bleeds into the marriage and into the family and causes major concern in everyone, especially Johnny's wife Celia.  Some have commented that this is reminiscent of `Days of Wine and Rose', the 1962 alcohol addiction film starring Lee Remick and Jack Lemmon.  I personally found that film over-the-top and forced.  This film feels more like Billy Wilder's `The Lost Weekend' in that it tackles the theme of addiction from a more subtle and honest place.  There is more grit here, more density.Eva Marie Saint should have been up for an Oscar here.  Her performance is staggering.  She really nails the desperation and pain that is saddled on the spouse of one suffering from such an illness, and she manages to make Celia so grounded, so real.  Anthony Franciosa was up for an Oscar, and he certainly deserved the attention.Like I said, there is a stagey atmosphere that isn't easily shaken, but overall this film truly transcends that detractor thanks to smart plotting and stellar performances by the cast.

Good score, not bad message movie about heroin, but Preminger and Nicholas Ray made better movies about it in this time frame. Nice NYC location shooting, and generally good acting, but this is one stagey play adaptation that never really feels like a movie, even w/ the location shooting. The trio of pushers are a hoot, though, with their all-American names of Mother, Church and Apples. 5/10

reviewText: I'm fond of the 1952-1960 period in American cinema when directors started to adapt the works of a new generation of writers describing the malaise of a society sick of its own lushness. Most of these films can be described as psychologically heavy according to our actual pretty low standards, I think here about the Tennesse Williams adaptations but, all in all, they can still provide a lot of fun to the curious movie lover sleeping inside you. Here's a film about drug addiction, a theme not so often handled in the mainstream Hollywood production of that period. Thanks to the performance of the cast - Bravo Eva Marie Saint, Henry Silva and Anthony Franciosa! - A Hatful of Rain doesn't dishonor Fred Zinnemann's filmography. Highly recommended.

reviewText: There are a few minor obstacles to appreciating this film notably Fox's decision to present it in pan and scan instead of its intended widescreen.  Secondly, the method which entails broad gestures and emoting by the actors may have been fashionable in 1957 but a little jarring for a modern audience.  Lastly it's stage origins are obvious but never fear.  Master director Fred Zinnemann expertly opens up Michael V. Gazzo's play from the tenement living rooms to the gritty streets of working class New York.  Bernard Herrmann offers another one of his patented stirring scores that is as essential to the film as the players.  The performances here are what stirs the drink.  Don Murray is careful not to overplay his part as the returning Korean vet with a heroin habit.  Eva Marie Saint, a beautiful woman, deglamorizes herself to play a working class spouse oblivious to her husband's drug use.  Henry Silva, whose character is ironically named Mother, is chilling as the sadistic drug dealer.  The film's heart and soul belongs to Anthony Franciosa.  Franciosa was nominated for an Oscar for his work here and justifiably so.  He plays Murray's bouncer brother who is at turns repulsed by his kin's addiction but ultimately his enabler because he bankrolls Murray's two bag a day habit while burning the torch for Saint.  "A Hatful of Rain" is an engrossing film that recalls other films that tackled the subject like "A Panic in Needle Park" and "Drugstore Cowboy".  I'm grateful it's available even in a less than ideal form.  At least Fox didn't colorize it.

reviewText: Never heard this term that alludes to apathy of the American population at the time, no sense of danger, alarm, or suspicion... if they had FaceBook guess the wall posts would include the excitement of LAUNDY DAY!!! vs incendiary comments on the economy, election, and armageddon... unclear of this vacuum souless perception but found the microcosm of suffering veterans a most poignant portrayal relevant even today... drug addiction despite the ubiquitous mainsteam media cashcow serves for entertainment value vs education, prevention, and successful solutions... was surprised the police were called to report drug addiction for assistance and surmise this approach prevented many from seeking the crucial help needed to consider rehabilitation... a scene I found helpful is when Pope wants to rob a helpless old man at gunpoint to pay for his next fix but his conscience actually overcame his withdrawls to recede into darkness... perhaps a plea for human decency may help others to negotiate this traumatic conflict... hard to imagine a wife so clueless about her husband's addiction but it happened to a 'friend' for two years, if you have no model to compare with and believe the convincing arguments despite many protests, it is a horror to comprehend how distant one is from anothers life... v. v. depressing and shakes your world to it's core for one's ability to trust and ameliorate the situation... high recommend for anyone even peripherally involved in substance abuse and the sorrowful experiences that produce such needs...

reviewText: This is a really good movie, especially if you're a fan of Eva Marie Saint. This movie is more "personal" to me because, not only was it filmed in a building adjacent to where my parents lived, but my mother was standing near the area where they were filming. During a break in filming, Ms Saint had walked over to my mother to see the baby she had in a carriage and then asked my mother if she could hold her baby. Of course, my mother was thrilled as Ms. Saint picked him up from the carriage and held him...even kissed him...according to my Mom! I loved this story because the baby in the carriage was, as you may have already guessed.....ME!
